headline.main: Overweight, but Ready to Fight; Obese People Are Taking Their Bias Claims to Court

docs.abstract: People are suing companies that refuse to hire them, or dismiss them, because of they are fat; some claim they are disabled under Americans With Disability Act, while others have shown more success with same law by claiming they are not disabled; among suits is Joseph Connor's against McDonald Corp; National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance and other advocates seek laws that would bar employment discrimination based on physical appearance; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: When Joseph Connor was offered a job as a cook at a McDonald's here, he finally seemed to have found a way to help support his five children. But along came a snag. The McDonald's manager told Mr. Connor, who is 6-foot-1 and weighs nearly 420 pounds, that he could start work as soon as his specially ordered uniform arrived. He waited days, then weeks, then months.

headline.main: If You Pitch It, They Will Eat

docs.abstract: Marketing of fast food, snacks and beverages to children, once confined to Saturday-morning television, has intensified and spread to Nickelodeon, movies, video games, Internet and even school; companies view this advertising and associated tie-ins as harmless, but they are under attack in court, legislatures and school boards; some of fiercest critics call for outright ban on all food advertising aimed at children, who represent huge market, both in what them spend on their own and how their influence their parents' spending; television remains most powerful medium for selling to children, and some critics say that children often cannot differentiate programs from commercials and that food companies and producers of children's shows have helped blur line by creating characters that leap back and forth from pitchmen to program characters; drawing; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE McDonald's Corporation wants to be everywhere that children are. So besides operating 13,602 restaurants in the United States, it has plastered its golden arches on Barbie dolls, video games, book jackets and even theme parks.

headline.main: Executive Life; Business Lessons for a Law School C.E.O.

docs.abstract: Michael K Young, dean of George Washington University Law School for last five years, has improved school's standing by applying some of aggressive strategies used by turnaround specialists on ailing companies; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: AS more than a thousand lawyers-in-training head for George Washington University Law School for another year studying torts, antitrust and contracts, the school is emerging from a five-year turnaround effort with better qualified students, a faculty with more visibility and a spruced-up campus. Michael K. Young, the dean of the law school, said he applied some of the aggressive principles turnaround specialists use to revive troubled businesses, becoming one of a growing number of nonprofit executives relying on practices that originated in the corporate world.

headline.main: Coke Makes Up With Burger King Over Rigged Test Of Frozen Drink

docs.abstract: Coca-Cola Co settles differences with Burger King over Coke's rigged marketing test of Frozen Coke in several Virginia Burger King restaurants in June 2002; admits it paid Virginia man $10,000 to purchase hundreds of value meals, which included free Frozen Cokes; among other problems, Coke also faces employee compensation lawsuit, but long-term erosion in overall carbonated drink sales is greatest challenge company faces; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Sweeping aside one of the more embarrassing episodes it has faced recently, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had resolved its differences with Burger King over a rigged marketing test. In June, Coca-Cola admitted to manipulating a marketing test for Frozen Coke -- a slushy version of Coke -- in Burger King restaurants. Neither company would confirm the terms or conditions of their agreement, but Coke will retain Burger King as a client, helping it maintain its dominance over PepsiCo and Cadbury Schweppes in sales to fast-food restaurants.
